title: Ariel 5
name: The Ariel V Satellite
alttext: Artistic impression of Ariel 5 in orbit
descript: Ariel V was launched into a low inclination (2.8°) orbit from the San Marco launch platform in the Indian Ocean on 15 October 1974. The mission was a British-USA collaboration. The Science Research Council managed the project for the UK and GSFC/NASA for the USA. Ariel V was dedicated to monitoring the X-ray sky with a comprehensive payload. The mission ended in the spring of 1980.
features: Monitored the X-ray sky with six different instruments. Four instruments (RMC, HRPCS, Polarimeter/Spectrometer, and Scintillation Telescope) were aligned with the spin axis and studying the region of sky within ∼10 degree of the axis, with the other two experiments covering wide swaths of the sky.

instruments.name: Scintillation telescope
instruments.descript: Devoted to temporal and spectral studies of sources

instruments.name: All Sky Monitor (ASM)
instruments.descript: Pair of small pinhole cameras, viewing the entire sky outside of an ∼8° wide area around the spacecraft’s “south” pole. It was intended as an early detection system for transient events, and a continuous monitor of relatively bright (> 0.2 Crab) galactic sources

instruments.name: Sky Survey Instrument (SSI)
instruments.fov:
0.75° × 10.6° (FWHM) scanning
20° × 360° sky band along the satellite spin equator with each spin
instruments.descript: Pair of proportional counters with different energy coverage: 1.2–5.8 keV (LE) and 2.4–19.8 keV (HE). The primary sciences goals for the SSI was conducting a high-sensitivity survey of the sky and to obtain locations, intensities, and spectra of interesting sources.

highlights: Long-term monitoring of numerous X-ray sources
Discovery of several long period (minutes) X-ray pulsars
Discovery of several bright X-ray transients probably containing a black hole (e.g. A0620-00, Nova Mon 1975)
Establishing that Seyfert I galaxies (AGN) are a class of X-ray emitters
Discovery of iron line emission in extragalactic sources
archive: The HEASARC hosts lightcurves from the ASM, raw data, and the 3<sup>rd</sup> Ariel V catalog
